intro: Mutellina corsica var. corsica, commonly known as Corsican bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region, particularly Corsica. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue to violet flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or calcareous soils and thrives in sunny to partially shaded environments. It has narrow, lance-shaped leaves and is often found in coastal and mountainous areas. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and endemic species.
